abstract_summ: Results Patients with higher levels of D-dimer and those requiring intubation were at a higher risk of developing PE.The cumulative incidence of PE was assessed ant the clinical, analytical and radiological characteristics were compared between patients with and without PE.Data suggests a high incidence of pulmonary embolism (PE) in ventilated patients with COVID-19.Objective To analyze the risk factors for pulmonary embolism (PE) in patients infected with COVID-19.The main objective of our study is to assess cumulative incidence of pulmonary embolism (PE) in non critically ill COVID-19 patients and to identify its predicting factors associated to the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.
title_summ: Predicting factors for a challenging diagnosisPulmonary embolism in hospitalised patients with COVID-19Incidence and consequences of systemic arterial thrombotic events in COVID-19 patientsD-dimer in patients infected with COVID-19 and suspected pulmonary embolism.Incidence of pulmonary embolism in non-critically ill COVID-19 patients.
title_abstract_phrases: The cumulative incidence of PE was assessed ant the clinical, analytical and radiological characteristics were compared between patients with and without PE.Results Patients with higher levels of D-dimer and those requiring intubation were at a higher risk of developing PE.Incidence and consequences of systemic arterial thrombotic events in COVID-19 patientsA high incidence of thrombotic events, particularly deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, has been clearly documented in COVID-19 patients.Data suggests a high incidence of pulmonary embolism (PE) in ventilated patients with COVID-19.Objective To analyze the risk factors for pulmonary embolism (PE) in patients infected with COVID-19.
